There are so many romance movies with macho guys, damsels in distress, love at first sight, individuals destined for each other, etc. and the plot action in most movies seems to just always happen so ""perfectly.""

I want to see a romantic drama in which a shy, awkward guy gets the girl. And not the most beautiful, most popular girl in a given community, but rather the charming one who listens to his problems and laughs at his jokes, someone assertive and funny and opinionated and someone who will make the first move. I love watching romantic movies, but I want a story that I can relate to. There seem to be many movies that show a wide range of feelings and emotions in females, but I want to see one that also shows these feelings and emotions in males; we have feelings too!

Perhaps an idea for the filmwriters on campus?

this is an admirers post for all the first years out there. i'm a junior now, and i remember my first september on brown's campus really well. i'm not gonna lie - it kinda sucked. i felt really lonely, extremely homesick, and very out of place. shopping period and class registration stressed me the fuck out. i had a rapid onset case of impostor syndrome that i could not shake. i felt like i'd conned my way into this school, like i'd somehow gamed the system. the other students in my seminars were outrageously bright - they were making references i didn't understand, they were cool as cucumbers during in class presentations, they made the professor laugh. meanwhile, i choked on my words every time i had to say anything in front of a group larger than 10, and i slowly started feeling like my educational background was completely useless, like my high school teachers had let me down by failing to teach me things these other kids knew. i looked around and felt like every other kid i'd met had found a solid, beautiful, funny, fun-loving group of friends. the type you see in the movies. and i hadn't found that. at all. i had acquaintances, i felt, but no one who liked me more than that. i wasn't invited out very frequently. i didn't feel appreciated. i didn't feel like i mattered here. 

and to top it all off, everyone else i spoke to or met seemed to be having the total opposite experience - if it wasn't the best week or month of their life, it was surely the best year. 

i'm here to tell you that if you're feeling lost, or scared, or homesick, or sad --- trust me when i tell you that there are others feeling the same way. more than you know! i found that, come second semester, more and more people were admitting to me that they'd spent nights crying in the bathroom when they felt unprepared for an exam, or saturdays in the library or their rooms, having not been invited to a single party. 

i'm writing all of this because i remember how desperately i had wished for someone to write something like this for me back when i was a first year. how desperately i just wanted one person to admit that adjusting is hard, and that sometimes it might take 2 or 3 months, or even 2 or 3 years! 

if you're a first year having the best time of your life this month - i applaud you! that's sick, and i'm really happy for you. but if you're not...i'm here to tell you that i didn't, either. and that this september feels about 500x better than that first september did. i admire you guys so much. adjusting is fucking HARD! and you're doing it! as hard as it may feel. you're all amazing and totally worthy of being here at Brown. in your own special ways.

To clarify about 302, I was talking about the kind of people who might spend at least $100 every time they go grocery shopping, every two weeks that they go, while I'm just with them, buying a box of blueberries that I know I can get cheaper elsewhere, that I know I'm only buying because I'm embarrassed not to buy anything. People who always complain about the 'Financial Struggle™ ' whenever it comes up in conversation with friends who are actually struggling. People who say they really need to work extra shifts this semester but won't bat an eyelash spending more than two hundred dollars for a single night stay in a hotel room ""because it was too much of a hassle to wait in the airport for the 2AM flight"". People who don't have to calculate every time they look at a menu because they're not thinking about how much is in their bank account or how they have to pay off their credit card. The list goes on.
Like I was trying to comment on people at Brown who are actually okay money-wise, like they know it, AND act like or sometimes outright lie that they're also struggling financially. I'm not sure if it's their twisted way of being sympathetic or whatever, but my actual struggles are not an opportunity for people like that to throw themselves a fake pity party. Like it's not a bad thing for people to have nice things, regardless of where they are with money, but lying about how textbooks are so expensive when you bought a new pair of Coach shoes to add to a literal collection is not okay. Money issues are real things people go through, literally every waking moment, and anyone who fakes it for some sick satisfaction in playing a victim is not only disrespectful but probably has their own stuff to work through.
Sorry my original post was lacking in nuance or whatever—I'm just sick of these fake ass hoes

Today was pretty exhausting and I was in a shit mood. On the way back to my room, I saw someone had wrote on the whiteboards in the study rooms near me. Thought it was graffiti, turned out to be a bunch of wholesome messages like "Have a good day." So thanks to you (or y'all) who did that, improved my mood.

@ post 270 (person who complained about the paper straws and joked about selling plastic ones). You probably think that one campus using plastic straws will make a minimal difference in the long run. You're right. But in order for us to move to a sustainable future, we have to start somewhere. It's not just about pretending we care about the environment to make ourselves feel better (though you're right, we probably do that sometimes). It's about making people aware that a bunch of small things can lead to big changes. First it's paper straws, maybe one day all of our disposable utensils are biodegradable.

Basically yeah, I know the paper straws suck to drink out of (no pun intended). But we have to take small steps before we can make big changes.

And who knows? In a few years someone will probably develop a biodegradable straw that isn't awful!!

To all t he people getting sad about being rejected from clubs:
I just want to say (as a person who has been involved in making decisions for several clubs) that it is actually a shitty process. It matters a lot whether you know someone in it, whether they like your attitude, whether you made an awkward face or said something mildly awkward, etc. I have had people reject applicants for the pettiest reasons (including not being smily enough or being awkward while greeting the people in the room). People claim that Brown is a place where you can try new stuff but tbh Brown has limited so many of my hobbies because I was not amazing at them. I have been rejected from so many clubs that I truly wanted to participate in and learn more about merely because I was not freaking AWESOME at them. My advise? If those !@#$%^& do not believe in you, YOU believe in yourself. Do not quit, do not give up. Find a group of people and do it independently. Do not let petty stuff get in the way of your passion.

To everyone struggling during midterm season, especially the freshmen who are taking their first ever college exams: I’m fairly sure that this year will be filled with ups and downs, moments of joy and suffering, revelations and realizations. My only wish for you, when you feel like you’re suffering, is to think about what your best friend would say to you, and then to speak to yourself using their warmth. Too often, we berate ourselves for “underperforming” and fail to show ourselves the compassion we so readily give to others. So please, seek help if you are suffering, but in the meantime, know that you deserve compassion just as much as anyone else. Believe in yourself because people believe in you. I believe in you. -Brown ‘15

I saw Tim Wang at The Andrews commons yesterday. I told him how cool it was to meet him in person, but I didn’t want to be a douche and bother him and ask him for photos or anything. He said, “Oh, like you’re doing now?” I was taken aback, and all I could say was “Huh?” but he kept cutting me off and going “huh? huh? huh?” and closing his hand shut in front of my face. I walked away and continued standing in the long poke line, and I heard him chuckle as I walked off. When I came to swipe for my poke I saw him trying to walk out the doors with like fifteen coffee mills in his hands without paying. The girl at the counter was very nice about it and professional, and was like “Sir, you need to pay for those first.” At first he kept pretending to be tired and not hear her, but eventually turned back around and brought them to the counter. When she took one of the milks and started scanning it multiple times, he stopped her and told her to scan them each individually “to prevent any electrical infetterence,” and then turned around and winked at me. I don’t even think that’s a word. After she scanned each bar and put them in a bag and started to say the price, he kept interrupting her by yawning really loudly.

I'm admiring my new baby orchid but I also wanted to share some tips:

1. Don't top water your orchid. Phalaenopsis orchids grow upside down in situ, meaning water runs out of the main crown of the plant and water build-up can rot and kill the orchid. Pour water into the media and over the roots. Allow water to completely drain from the pot and don't leave the orchid sitting in standing water. 
2. Ditch the moss, and invest in some epiphytic orchid media. Anything that is nutrient-poor, loose and airy works (just google orchid bark). Don't use potting soil. Phal roots grow exposed to the air and need constant air flow to not suffocate, so moss is a generally terrible idea.
3. Don't expose the poor thing to full sun. Seriously, don't give your plant sunburns. We haven't invented lather-on plant sunscreen yet.
4. Green roots = happy and moist, Silvery-gray roots = dry and sad. Orchids don't like being dry and sad
5. Polish the leaves. They get caked in dust so keep them nice and shiny.
6. Don't chop off the weird, noodly things that grow from the sides of the plant. Those are its aerial roots and are very important to the plant. It's like cutting a guy's dick off. Don't do it. 
Abuse your baby, and your soul will be forever tainted with the stench of death.

-signed, a person with a 10+yrs of carnivorous plant and orchid growing experience

I admire admiration. To admire something not only requires that one achieve the level of awareness necessary to recognize something worthy of admiration, but it also often necessitates that one have the self-esteem to consider one's own opinions significant enough to define what is praiseworthy. Such mental fortitude is truly a rare and admirable quality. In fact, by admiring admiration, I am committing an act that I find admirable. My open advocacy for my beliefs on this matter resonates strongly with me. I now admire myself.

I feel overwhelmed facing the next couple of weeks. I think if I could just spend time with the friend I like beyond the brief conversation of this semester's coincidental meetings, I would be more confident in my ability to pull through the work. But such a wish is futile. If I asked, it would be unexpected. And the unexpected could elicit a negative response. You might say that I should reach out anyways, that if the friendship is strong, there is nothing to lose. But let's be honest. We say we're scared of ruining a friendship, but we're actually afraid of closing the door to something more.
I love you, but I can’t tell you. I want you to be happy, but I wish it was me that made you happy.

I've been seeing a number of posts on here about feeling uneasy as a first year, feeling friendless and purposeless (regardless of year), etc. I just wanted to say this - I am an upperclassman at Brown and I continue to struggle with feelings like this. Sometimes they come in waves, sometimes just droplets. But I'd also never have the courage to comment on or even like a post about these feelings. But I admire those of you who have written them. And I'm with you! There are a lot of us at Brown who struggle with these feelings all the damn time and just don't say anything! So many more than would ever like a post about it. So stay strong, whoever you are. It makes me feel so much better when people share that they feel out of it in the same way I do.

Shoutout to SEAS, thank you guys so much. It's been really hard to fight for academic accommodations in this one class. The professor doesn't seem to care about my disability. I feel like I have to prove that I'm worth accommodating at every step; my class performance and attendance are put under a microscope, scrutiny most students in larger classes don't have to face. I hope my professor changes her mind soon.

I sent this post in twice last year, but it never got posted, so I’m hoping the third time is the charm. Sometime back in April/May, on what I believe was a Thursday afternoon, there was a guy in the ratty wearing a Trump 2016 shirt.

To that guy: I would like to say that I wholeheartedly admire your confidence and your willingness to challenge what seems to be a general consensus that everyone at Brown is a Democrat. I may not agree with your political choices, but I sincerely appreciate that you’re not afraid to share them. 

To everyone else reading this: emotions are absolutely a valid response to recent events, but that is likely not going to change anyone’s mind. If you want to convince people to agree with you, you have to understand where they and their difference of opinion come from. People can be persuaded; it just takes some effort and civil conversation.

I think it’s important to not identify the person you admire by their race/ethnicity. I’d have thought this goes without saying at a place like Brown, but posting things like “Indian women on this campus are hot” or “Asian guy in my CS15 class is cute” is normalising attraction based on race. It can offend the people you admire to feel that they are nothing more than their race to you. That’s not only institutionalised racism but that’s also you invalidating a person’s individuality, and reducing their identity to a race/ethnicity and you have no right to do that, not even if you identify by that same race/ethnicity yourself. You can’t presume to know someone’s identity by their physical appearance- calling them out on that, even in a positive way, may not be the best idea, and definitely not the best idea for a BBA post. As a woman of color, I’m constantly concerned about whether I’m being fetishisized by someone I think likes me, or am actually liked, and posts like these make me highly uncomfortable as I’m sure it does other people.

To all men: Before you decide that you like someone enough to kiss them, remember that they also get to decide whether they like you enough to kiss you.
Sometimes it’s not just about consent, sometimes it has to be about willingness. I don’t want to let you kiss me, I want to want to kiss you. And guess what? I have the right to do so.

I don't work for BUDS, but I see first hand how overworked these workers are. I am even more appalled when I see their wages and lack of compensation. As a Brown community we need to change the system to make a work environment that is not dangerous for our peers. I, like most students here, rely on my parents for tuition and necessities (I don't know what I would do if I had to work for BUDS... I am so lucky that I dont have to experience such horrible treatment). I am privileged, and it is highly likely that you reading this are very privileged as well. It is unfair that people who don't have the same privilege have to be suffering this much. They are students like you who have the same obligations. Let's change this.

Hello! There have been quite a few posts lately about people feeling unworthy, and I want to address that really quickly. As a former Meiklejohn for three years and a former TA of two of the largest introductory classes at Brown, I’ve witnessed people transition from uneasy, insecure first-years to ridiculously successful graduates. And by “ridiculously successful,” I don’t necessarily mean they’ve had to have found a cure for ALS or Parkinson’s or whatever. I mean that I have yet to look at a SINGLE former student of mine and think to myself “wow this person hasn't made any progress” because the obvious truth is that every one of them has made enormous progress. You might not recognize it yourself, but other people absolutely do. I hope you have the faith to believe that you will make a difference. If you’re a first-year, you have quite a way to go, and if you’re a senior, chances are you’ve already come a long way without realizing it. I continue to be proud of you and my alma mater ❤️

I hooked up with a guy for the first time last night. He was gentle and sweet and very respectful of what I wanted. In many ways, the encounter was perfect- the straight out of movies kind of perfect. I knew going into it that it was just a hook up, and I knew when we decided to see each other again, that we would just do that because we enjoyed the sex. And yet, my heart feels empty and somewhat heavy- almost as though something is horribly wrong. Usually I am sad when I like people who don’t like me back, and I can put my finger on in the exact moment, the exact instant and the precise cause for my sadness. But something about this situation makes it different. It’s not that I feel attached to him, nor do I regret that night. I also do want to keep hooking up with him and other people. Yet why does it feel that isn’t how it was supposed to go down? Why can I not accept that all those little gestures and moments that only happen in sweeping tales of romance, are nothing more than an empty physical, with no heart? I mean i understand that heteronormativity is a social construct, and marriage and monogamy are all constructed, so why can my heart and head not reconcile? Why can’t I give up on those idealistic notions and take what’s given to me?

To the CS TAs--
Sorry for being mean. 
Recently I waited in hours lines for approximately 5.5 hours before being seen. I have been sleep deprived the last few days, and in order to avoid the risk of being skipped in line, I hadn't eaten anything. I was hungry, sad, and irritable, and I tried to still remain respectful of my TA, but I was just too exhausted to try. I'm sorry to the TAs whose feelings I may have hurt as a result of my non-CS related life problems. I feel really guilty about being so rude, but after waiting for so long and still getting no support, I was frustrated and on the verge of giving up. Thanks to the great TAs, and the superstar TAs who tolerate our anger and still try their hardest to help us every day.

Hi, not exactly an admirer's post, but I don't know what else to do.
I am a CS15 student and I'm struggling in the course due to the collaboration policy mixed with the lack of TA hours. I keep not being seen because I cannot put my entire night on hold just to wait for 15 minutes of office hours - and the new hours policy has made it worse. As a result my mental health and grades have gone down, but I cannot drop this course for other reasons. I have tried asking the TAs what to do and I was either told that everyone struggles (all the more reason to do something about this class) or to talk the the HTAs. I emailed the HTAs asking for help and explaining that I - and anyone with other commitments - can't reasonably do all of this with the very limited resources they give us and only 24 hrs in a day. I even made suggestions of small steps that would help. So far they have yet to respond to me. 
I know I am not the only one who is being actively harmed by and is not ok with this class. Does anyone know what I can do and/or to whom I can go. I am really struggling and am really sick of being ignored by a class ""open to everyone"". Any advice for me or any other student feeling this way would be greatly appreciated.
Lastly, a huge thank you to all CS15 TAs! You are the reason anyone passes this course! I know you put up with a lot and are short-staffed, you are all saints!

So I've got this theory (this is especially for my underclassmen but also whoever needs it) that absolutely no one on this campus has a fantastic perfect amazing life and NO ONE'S reality is as beautiful and lovely as it is presented on social media. No one's. 

What I've come to find in my time at Brown (and it's taken A LOT of time and energy and sadness to find this) is that if someone isn't struggling socially, they might be struggling academically. And if they're not struggling academically, they're probably struggling with extracurriculars. And if that's not a struggle for them, then job and internship-hunting is. And if they seem to be perfect at that, I can guarantee you that they're having an issue with their concentration or their friend group or their family or their finances.....the list goes on. And very very few people will cop to any of these issues, especially publicly. Which makes us all feel like we're behind in a race that doesn't even exist! 

The point I'm trying to impart (especially to our younger students on campus) is that the person whose life you see on Instagram, who you envy, who seems to have endless supplies of whatever it is you're looking for (whether that's friends or parties or money or good grades or job offers or success in extracurricular endeavors) - I absolutely, unequivocally guarantee you that their life is much harder than it appears to be. So please don't waste your energy comparing yourself! I wish I could go back to my freshman or sophomore self and capture back alllllll of the energy and time I spent worrying about how my life stacked up to everyone else's, because as I spoke to the people I envied so much, I always came to discover that they were either struggling in a very silent way or even envied some portion of my life! 

Let's all be a little easier on ourselves, please!

To #1774)
Ouch. Sounds like you're having a tough time. That sucks. I've been there, so I kinda know what you're talking about. I've been in the ever circling vortex of self doubt, frustration, and loathing. It's no bueno. I know. If you don't mind lemme tell you a couple things. You can read em if you want, read em again later if you feel like it. But honestly man, if I spend all this time typing this out to you and you don't let it be a little tinder for your fire, well, you're just letting us both down. And you don't HAVE to do that. You don't HAVE to do anything. But you get to choose.

(Who am I? My name’s Alex and I’m a freshman. Just moved to a new city for a dream job that I got because of the rules below. I owe a lot of my success to people much cooler, kinder, more loving and greater than me. When I get the chance to maybe let a little bit of help out, it’s a way of thanking them. )

Rule numero uno - There are no more zero days. What's a zero day? A zero day is when you don't do a single fucking thing towards whatever dream or goal or want or whatever that you got going on. No more zeros. I'm not saying you gotta bust an essay out everyday, that's not the point. The point I'm trying to make is that you have to make yourself, promise yourself, that the new SYSTEM you live in is a NON-ZERO system. Didnt' do anything all fucking day and it's 11:58 PM? Write one sentence. One pushup. Read one page of that chapter. One. Because one is non zero. You feel me? When you're in the super vortex of being bummed your pattern of behaviour is keeping the vortex goin, that's what you're used to. Turning into productivity ultimate master of the universe doesn't happen from the vortex. It happens from a massive string of CONSISTENT NON ZEROS. That's rule number one. Do not forget.

La deuxieme regle - yeah i learnt french. its a canadian thing. please excuse the lack of accent graves, but lemme get into rule number 2. BE GRATEFUL TO THE 3 YOU'S. Uh what? 3 me's? That sounds like mumbo jumbo bullshit. News flash, there are three you's homeslice. There's the past you, the present you, and the future you. If you wanna love someone and have someone love you back, you gotta learn to love yourself, and the 3 you's are the key. Be GRATEFUL to the past you for the positive things you've done. And do favours for the future you like you would for your best bro. Feeling like shit today? Stop a second, think of a good decision you made yesterday. Salad and tuna instead of Big Mac? THANK YOU YOUNGER ME. Was yesterday a nonzero day because you wrote 200 words (hey, that's all you could muster)? THANK YOU YOUNGER ME. Saved up some coin over time to buy that sweet thing you wanted? THANK YOU. Second part of the 3 me's is you gotta do your future self a favour, just like you would for your best fucking friend (no best friend? you do now. You got 2. It's future and past you). Tired as hell and can't get off reddit/videogames/interwebs? fuck you present self, this one's for future me, i'm gonna rock out p90x Ab Ripper X for 17 minutes. I'm doing this one for future me. Alarm clock goes off and bed is too comfy? Screw you present self, this one's for my best friend, the future me. I'm up and going for a 5 km run (or 25 meter run, it's gotta be non zero). MAKE SURE YOU THANK YOUR OLD SELF for rocking out at the end of every.single.thing. that makes your life better. The cycle of doing something for someone else (future you) and thanking someone for the good in your life (past you) is key to building gratitude and productivity. Do not doubt me. Over time you should spread the gratitude to others who help you on your path.

Rule number 3- don't worry i'm gonna too long didnt' read this bad boy at the bottom (get a pencil and piece of paper to write it down. seriously. you physically need to scratch marks on paper) FORGIVE YOURSELF. I mean it. Maybe you got all the know-how, money, ability, strength and talent to do whatever is you wanna do. But lets say you still didn't do it. Now you're giving yourself shit for not doing what you need to, to be who you want to. Heads up champion, being dissapointed in yourself causes you to be less productive. Tried your best to have a nonzero day yesterday and it failed? so what. I forgive you previous self. I forgive you. But today? Today is a nonzero masterpiece to the best of my ability for future self. This one's for you future homes. Forgiveness man, use it. I forgive you. Say it out loud.

Last rule. Rule number 4, is the easiest and its three words. exercise and books. that's it. Pretty standard advice but when you exercise daily you actually get smarter. when you exercise you get high from endorphins (thanks body). when you exercise you clear your mind. when you exercise you are doing your future self a huge favour. Exercise is a leg on a three legged stool. Feel me? As for books, almost every fucking thing we've all ever thought of, or felt, or gone through, or wanted, or wanted to know how to do, or whatever, has been figured out by someone else. Get some books max. Post to about BBA about struggling with friends? Good first step! (nonzero day, thanks younger me for typing it out) You know what else you could do? Read 7 habits of highly successful people. Read ""emotional intelligence"". Read ""From good to great"". Read “thinking fast and slow”. Read books that will help you understand. Read the bodyweight fitness reddit and incorporate it into your workouts. (how's them pullups coming?) Reading is the dang warp whistle from Super Mario 3. It gets you to the next level that much faster.

That’s about it man. There’s so much more when it comes to how to turn nonzero days into hugely nonzero days, but that’s not your mission right now. Your mission is nonzero and forgiveness and favours. You got 36 essays due in 24 minutes and its impossible to pull off? Your past self let you down big time, but hey… I forgive you. Do as much as you can in those 24 minutes and then move on.

I hope I helped a little bit max. I could write about this forever, but I promised myself I would go do a 15 minute run while listening to A. Skillz Beats Working Vol. 3. Gotta jet. One last piece of advice though. Regardless of whether or not reading this for the first time helps make your day better, if you wake up tomorrow, and you can’t remember the 4 rules I just laid out, please, please. Read this again.

Have an awesome day ☺

tldr; 1. Nonzero days as much as you can. 2. The three you’s, gratitude and favours. 3. Forgiveness 4. Exercise and books (which is a sneaky way of saying self improvement, both physical, emotional.

This is an admirers post for everyone who didn't get invited anywhere this Halloweekend (or who simply doesn't like to partake in the partying). For everyone who is going to sit in their rooms alone and hear everyone else having (what seems like) a good time. Big party weeks like this can SUCK for a lot of people. 

As an offering of hope, I want to say to all those people (especially first years) - I had a HORRIBLE Halloweekend last year. No one invited me anywhere. I had maybe 2 friends on campus at the time, and they either didn't want to do anything or were going out without me. I sat in my room, alternating between crying and scrolling through Instagram looking at everyone else having the best time. 

This year I've already had a blast doing things with new friends I've made! It definitely gets better. 

And guess what? If it doesn't? Halloweekend isn't actually THAT fun. You aren't missing much! Half the time I just wish I were in my room watching TV. People construct false realities on social media. I've been to some grungy, humid, nasty, boring basement parties that have been filtered into oblivion on Instagram. Suddenly they seem like the party of the century. But they weren't. 

Either way, I'm with you! Please don't lose hope or feel too bad. There are soooo many kids like you on campus!

This is an admiration post for everyone who’s not really happy here at Brown. It kind of pains me to say this, because as much as it might be comforting to hear, it’s also a pretty bleak statement about the culture here, but, you aren’t alone.

I’m writing this post in hopes that in putting some of the negative things I feel about Brown into words, I might reach some sort of catharsis, and I’m hoping if you’re not doing so well right now or if any of this resonates with you in some way, this might be a bit cathartic for you too.

I’ve been here for about three years now, and naively, I keep expecting each new semester to be the one where I suddenly become happy, where I find friends that make me excited to wake up every day, or where I finally, if not start to love my life, at least find a bit of peace and contentment. I keep being wrong. 

For a while, I wondered if this was due to some personal failing of mine. Maybe I just didn’t fit in here. Maybe I was just too flawed to exist in a space like Brown or to warrant happiness here. And in full honesty, there might be a shred of truth in that: I’m not a perfect person. I have a lot of things that I can work on and a lot of room to be a better. Because of that, I worried that my unhappiness had just become a fact of life. That it was independent from Brown. That, barring some major self-transformation, I’d remain equally dissatisfied for the foreseeable future. 

At the height of this all, my health went to shit. My energy plummeted. I began to wonder if I had depression. And more than anything, I just needed a break.

So I took one.

I left Brown for a while, and, while it didn’t happen instantly, I felt better. I made a ton of friends I genuinely enjoyed being with. Most days, I woke up pretty excited. I grew a lot. I learned a lot. I felt healthy. And when it finally came time to come back to Brown, I was a bit anxious, but more so than ever I was hopeful. After being happy for so long, I could hardly imagine that it wouldn’t carry through to school. I was ready to be happy here at Brown.

I was wrong.

What I ended up realizing is that Brown just isn’t really a place for me. 

To some extent, I’m happy that I ended up here, because I really have been getting a great education, and I think it’s going to do me well after college is over. In truth, though, if I had a do-over, it’s not that I would come to Brown and just do things differently, I just wouldn’t have come to Brown in the first place.

Some cynical part of me wants to say that it’s the people here. Because I’ve met so many bitter people here at Brown. People who are constantly trying to prove something, people who need to feel like they’re superior to you, people who never learned healthy social habits and who think they’re too smart to be at fault or need to change. Most of all, people who are also unhappy, but have been taught that their own self-care is more important than being a decent human being and people who encourage them to continue believing that.

And, honestly, I feel like there’s more than a shred of truth in all of that. And that there’s dozens of other issues with how people at this school act that I could rant about for days. But I don’t think that so many people here would act in these sorts of ways if there weren’t a deeper problem with the culture here in general. So, most of all,

I don’t like Brown because it’s not valid to be unhappy here. 

I think maybe it’s because Brown has the reputation of being such a happy place. It’s because when you take the tour here, everyone is smiling, and people will shout at you that you should come here, and you’ll love it. But the end result is that when we feel unhappy here we tend to think there’s something wrong with us or that we don’t belong here. And when we’re sad and feel like there’s something wrong with us, it’s pretty easy to be bitter. It’s pretty easy to try to latch onto anything that makes it seem like people like us more.

But even more so, I don’t like Brown because it’s so easy to be lonely here.

Maybe that’s why so many of us are sad in the first place. Despite being surrounded by people all the time, despite having periods of my college life where I’ve had a lot of friends, I never really found people I actually felt comfortable opening up to or that I was able to really get close with. I’m not completely sure why. Maybe it’s because we’re all putting on acts and don’t like the acts that everyone else is putting on. I don’t know.

What I do know is that I’m not unique in any of this. The number of people who’ve eventually revealed to me that they’re unhappy here has been staggering. The number of people who’ve told me they suffer from serious anxiety and depression which got worse when they came here, the people who’ve told me they engage in self-harm, the people who’ve told me they felt suicidal or have attempted suicide while here. It occasionally leaves me wondering if Brown is really the place for anyone.

I hope it is. I hope that there are a bunch of people out there who are happy here and have managed to be happy without hurting other people or making them unhappy instead. I tend to believe this less and less the more people I get to know.

In any case, though, know that if you’re not doing so well at Brown, you’re not alone. You’re not an anomaly or a freak. Being sad here doesn’t mean that there’s something wrong with you or that you don’t belong here. I’m not telling you that it will pass or that if you’re sad here, it will eventually go away, but despite the fact it often doesn’t feel like it, this is the beginning of our lives, not the end or the peak. If you’re thinking about taking some time off, going abroad, or even transferring, that’s more than valid. If you need to take one fewer class or take something S/NC because you’re extra low on energy this semester, that’s valid too.

For me, I’m going to keep on hoping and doing my best to make each semester be the one that finally makes me happy here. I don’t really think it’s going to happen, but hey, I don’t have too many more to go. But really, more than anything, I just hope you all find a bit more happiness here than I did.

I’m a little worried about showing up to CS15 TA hours tomorrow. I came to hours a couple times very recently and although it was super helpful as always, I was unable to meet minimum functionality for DoodleJump by the on time deadline and will now have to submit it by the late deadline. I worry that tomorrow and/or day after my questions won’t be appreciated as most everyone else coming to hours will be getting a head start on Tetris, and internally the TAs will think that I should’ve gotten this done earlier. I can’t help it though as I just had an insane two weeks and have barely slept as of late. I just worry that sometimes the student-CS15 TA dynamic may be too similar to that of a student-professor dynamic in that the TAs might internally disapprove of such inefficiency and bad planning, so I hope that the TAs won’t judge me for not being on top of things and scrambling to address various problems at this late time. This is mainly my fear and self consciousness talking, as I’d also just like to say that I’m forever grateful to all of them for being so patient, helpful, and responsive in hours or on Piazza, making the course fun, and creating amazing, easy to understand PowerPoints. I guess I’m just super worried about being judged.

I sometimes get asked out by white/rich boys who seem super interested and nice. We go out on a date and it seems like they have genuine interest, but eventually I realize they don't want to be in a committed relationship. They seem ashamed to introduce a woman of color to their family and friends. They might be willing to keep me around for a bit, but at the end of the day, being a low income WOC seems to be too much for them to handle. I believe I am so smart and beautiful, and yet, I feel so invalidated at Brown because of these experiences. To all women of color who have experienced something similar: you are beautiful, strong and resilient. You all deserve to be treasured and treated like the queens you are.

I'm queer enough to want a close friendship with other queer people but I'm not queer enough for them to accept me. Sometimes it really feels like you're either straight or gay in many people's eyes.
- If you're bi/pan
- If you're trans but ""don't look it""
- If you're nb
- If you're queer
- If you're closeted
- If you're questioning
You belong! The community can feel unwelcoming sometimes towards people who ""appear"" cishet, but I promise you'll find people who you will grow to love and trust and who you can discover yourself with. I love you!

To the other people who are unhappy at Brown for a variety of reasons, I had an experience today that I hope can help you like it helped me. It wasn't something groundbreaking, but it made a huge difference for me - I got off campus. When I woke up today and looked out my window I could see how beautiful it was outside, but when I got out of bed and headed to class the beauty of the day was lost to me. I tried desperately to find it because I knew if I did it would make me happy, but it was nowhere to be found. After my class ended, I sought it elsewhere. I walked off campus, down the hill a bit to Prospect Park, and there it was. The cool air, the scattered leaves, the clear sky, all combined and it was as if a fog cleared from my eyes. I felt really happy for the first time in a long time. After a while I had to return to campus for more classes, and though nothing about the weather or the day changed, I could no longer see what I saw off-campus earlier. For some reason, the campus itself was muting it for me, and that was kind of revelatory. Yet for the rest of the day I carried that happiness in me and friends even noted the change. 
I find it really easy while on the hill to think that the world ends at the foot of the hill. The surrounding city and towns blur away, and the hill and its inhabitants feel like all there is. I think today made more clear to me that I have to challenge that regularly and make myself push that boundary, because beyond it is where I can be reminded about the rest of the world and the beauty and happiness in it. I think I will start trying to schedule off-hill time to help achieve that, whether that means going back to Prospect or India Point Park, walking/riding along the East Bay Bike Path, or even just sitting and doing work at the mall where I can be surrounded by people who look more like the rest of the world and less like the microcosm that is Brown. I think that will be very helpful for me, and I hope that it can be helpful for some of you as well. Don't give up, you deserve happiness and it is out there, even if you can't find it within the confines of this campus. And if anyone needs a friend to get off-campus with let me know, or just find me off the hill :)

I'd hoped that we would see Gillum and O'Rourke and Abrams come to office last night. But I keep reminding myself that this movement isn't built on hope, it's built on "fuck how hopeless this seems, we're going to show up on your goddamn lawn and be heard regardless." We just have to keep being loud, and present, and leverage our privilege where it exists to drag change from our local and state institutions one inch at a time. We didn't get to where we are today in one decade, much less one election, and we won't get out of it in one election either. And I'm disappointed, I'm tired, I've been tired, but I also have so much respect for how far we've come and how much has been sacrificed to get us here.

All this talk about voting and elections over the past few weeks has got me down. Without getting into specifics, I'm from a...not so democratic country. I'm studying at Brown, but I'm not a U.S citizen. Please be conscious of your words because, at a diverse place like Brown, you never know who's around you who doesn't share the same privileges as you. Imagine a wealthy student talking about her yacht and beach house while sitting next to a low income student. When people around me talk about voting and selecting between candidates, I feel like that low income student. I wish I wasn't born in the country I was and had the privilege of democracy, but I don't. So all I ask is that my peers at Brown are more mindful of situations like these. Thanks!

Few lines composed on the CIT 5th floor balcony, On 
Revisiting the 2nd highest tower of the Sciences Quad during a Tour. November 10, 2018 

Five weeks have past; five weekends, with the length
Of five long Algos homeworks! and again I see
These sunsets, rolling from the mediocre sky-line of Providence
With a tender, brewing murmur. -Once again
Do I behold these soft but violent orange, pinkish glows,
That on a tame and cold scene impress
Thoughts of more confused introspection; and connect
The landscape of students clustering like ants
Around tables outside the Scili
With the stillness of the sky.
The day is come when I again repose
Here, next to this broken hammock, and view
These plots of college-ground, these intellectual-cuffs,
Which, at this senior season, with my unripe fruits of job-search,
Make me doubt why I am studying CS in the first place.

Tag a meme master

Hi, so um, I've never... written a BBA like this. Usually just for friends or random people doing something beautiful (I guess that includes existing?)... but never like this. I'm also super nervous, not just because I'm afraid of what this person'll think, or because I don't want people to casually talk about my feelings in the comments, or just for fear of this coming off as cheesy or inconsequential or some other thing I should be afraid of. But because... well, I really like this person, and that makes me nervous. Nothing new on BBA, right? 
I guess I need to put this out there, for this person to know or at least to work through it on my own. Uhh, I haven't had this happen in all my time at Brown—which was a relief, believe me—but regardless, I really like this one person. Actually the sweetest person I've met in college, possibly ever. And ridiculously smart—and not just Brown smart, like actually boutta-f*ck-up-their-industry-and-maybe-the-world smart. Really funny too, the whole thing going on.
And I get that when you like someone, everything about them is beautiful, and maybe that's what's happening here, or maybe that's just who this person is. Independent of whether I like him, I'd like to think his smile is still so bright it's almost unacceptable, and the way he says ""sweet"" after something goes right is just as endearing, and gosh, he's such a dork it makes me want to cry. Also his ears turn pink when he laughs, and he just has this whole 'good-natured' feel about him, and I can't help but think that he's so soft and that I want to hold his face. He's so nice to listen to, not just because his voice sounds nice, but also because he's so nerdy in a really comfortable way, and it's oddly soothing. He also has the most interesting face, and I always end up doodling that objectively good nose and and really strong widow's peak, but of course I can't do him any justice. It doesn't help that I have the feeling he gives really good hugs, and he'd be so nice to be held by...
There's so much more about him, but this is already longer than I told myself I'd allow it to be. He most definitely doesn't know who this is from, probably because I'm sure there are plenty of people weak for him, and also because he makes me too shy to have made an impression on him. So yeah, that's been my incredibly cowardly confession. Take it as it is, and I'll just... I'll just leave it at that.

Hi, I would really like some opinions on this:

I met a girl recently that I really like and have gotten to know her to a certain extent. However, she has a boyfriend, my friends are telling me that I shouldn't try to go forward because of this. Please forgive my language, but why do I care if she has a boyfriend? Like, I'll let her know how I feel and that I like her and want to get to know her, and if she rejects me that's cool. I don't mind that. But to not even try? What if she, or any other girl in this situation for that matter is the love of my life? Nothing against the other guy, but if she were to theoretically break up with him because of me, doesn't that mean they weren't meant to be in the first place?

S/o to all the non-monogamous folks on campus - whether you’re partnered or not, you deserve love and respect!

As an ethically non-monogamous woman myself, I have really tried to keep my composure over your post. It’s a little humorous, this idea of being “too woke.” But I can tell you, for myself, my partners, and the precious few other non-mono folks I know on campus, that we don’t live this way to be “woke.” And I’m flat-out pissed that you would insinuate that.

I agree that it is icky when a guy says that he’s “woke” because of the fact that he’s in a non-mono relationship or is considering one. But if someone you admire to be woke for other reasons is questioning why monogamy is the dominant relationship structure in our society, maybe listen a moment before dismissing him? Mononormativity (like the post that you made) hurts. It says that I shouldn’t love my partners, or be happy for them finding love with other people, or seek out friendship with their partners or wish for a day when we can all live together. In some states, my love is a literal crime. 

Seeing all those people react positively to your sentiment validates your demonization of non-mono people and honestly makes me sad.

To be clear, I have no problem with people who practice monogamy, and when dating I try to be as transparent as possible about my non-monogamous status. I also don’t think a la Sex At Dawn that everyone should be non-monogamous — but it should be an option. Mononormative society only allows for people to be single, or monogamous, or cheat (aka, non-ethically non-monogamous). Creating space for non-monogamous options is difficult because it challenges the way we’ve been taught to think about love, sex, and power. And I want that choice for everyone.

Wokeness doesn't have any correlation to relationship structure, and treating non-monogamous folks as ""too woke"" is distressingly dismissive. I hope you find someone to enjoy a monogamous relationship with and shares your values, but please don't treat people who structure their relationships differently from you as worse people for it.

Eric Kim-
I see you all the time, but it’s always from a distance. We’ve never actually been introduced, but we’ve been face to face on numerous occasions, and I’d like to think on most subjects we see eye to eye, even though we’re so different. I work all night and you work all day, and everyday our paths cross, but I can’t change my schedule and I know you can’t change yours, so I guess we’ll just have to keep it that way. I know I am one of many, know there are countless others chasing after you, but I still can’t shake the feeling that our relationship is different; everyone likes to lump us together, our names and dominions go hand in hand, but in all honesty, we can never meet, not properly I mean. If we did, it might be like one of those things, where the universe implodes or something. Even though I’m small and cold and pale in comparison, I only shine because of you. Too bad we can’t meet up, I’ll have to love you from afar, but when it comes down to it, that’s the way it’s always been.
It’s right that you should be the center and leave all others to orbit in your wake.

Hot take: I’m a CS student and while there r some weirdos in this department (I mean there are weirdos everywhere some might consider me a weirdo) but I think there are so many genuinely kind people here. 2 of my best friends I have met through classes here, and so many people have helped me without expectation. I acknowledge that people flaunt about offers and what not (please don’t discuss your offers in public. Like, happy for you but I’m actually nauseated by people who say “of course I’m gonna take google but, (insert bullshit first world problem flaw)”. Like, shut the fuck up. Anyways, back to the positives. 

Sorry for the tangent. Don’t hate on the TAs. They work hard to see as many people as possible! And also, you can’t expect people to just be nice and collaborative. If they are, it’s a plus. The baseline is that they don’t fuck you over. And I haven’t heard of a case of anyone trying to fuck each other over yet. People know better than to do that. I think people in the CS department here uphold quite a high standard of moral & compassion.

Ok I’m done. And to sum up, this post is to admire the great people in CS

As the semester closes out, i wanted to give a special shoutout to everyone for making it through (GO US!!! seriously incredible and no small feat) but especially to the first years. I'm a sophomore, and last year at this time I was tired, lonely, burnt out, riddled with impostor syndrome and kind of sad. I'd made a few friends here and there, but I didn't feel comfortable on this campus AT ALL. In any way shape or form. Dealing with first semester (and frankly, the entire first two years of college) can be A LOT. For some of you, it may have been your best 3 months ever! To those people, I offer my sincerest congratulations. I'm happy for you. But for the rest of you who don't feel comfortable at Brown yet, who feel lonely, or isolated, or academically strained, or like the expectations at Brown in every area of life have been too much to bear, I offer this: I am in such a better place now than I was a year ago. And it will get better for you too - please believe that. Sheer repetition on this campus makes for comfort. Finding your favorite study spot in the library. Molding a routine that works for you. Saying hi to the same people you pass in the street on the way to class. Learning all the street names and building names simply by passing them by. Will you ever feel 100% comfortable here? Maybe not. I don't, many days. But the thing that's different is that now I've learned that it's ok to feel out of place here! I felt so much pressure my first year to fit in, to look like I was having the best time of my life, to report to my nosy and caring relatives that I was abundantly happy. Now I know that it's ok to take stock of everything, good and bad, comfort and discomfort, happiness and sadness, friendship and loneliness, A's and B's and C's and NC's (lol brown) and to accept it all for what it is instead of fighting it. To acknowledge that it might cause me pain or unease, and that those feelings are valid and ok. And that everyone has them - even if they paint a picture of perfection in public. Perfection simply isn't true for any person on this campus. 

So to all the first years who feel like this semester was the hardest 3 month span of your life - I can absolutely, 100% guarantee you that you are FAR from alone. Even though everyone else wants to make you feel like you're the only one struggling. You will come to realize you are not. I also want to incorporate a SPECIAL shoutout to my FLi first years - you guys have accomplished a miracle, truly, and should be bursting with pride, however this semester ends for you. I admire all of you so. damn. much. 

While I do know some of you personally (y'all are awesome), I don't know most of you.... but in both cases, I'm extremely proud of all of you for getting through your first semester in one of the most academically and socially and extracurricularly stringent environments in the country. You guys DID! THAT! And the beautiful thing about college is that every single semester is a completely blank slate, full of glorious potential for the things to come, things you can't even fathom.
I want to thank my boyfriend for making me feel more confident and beautiful in the past couple of months. Tag the wholesome guy (or guys!) in your life. ❤️

This one is for all the RPLs, TAs, Meiks, MAPS mentors, and other guides and confidants who are struggling. It can feel disempowering to know you have the tools to help someone in need but can't apply them to yourself. I feel disgusted with myself for having all these resources and the institutional knowledge to access them while still falling behind. We stretch ourselves too thin and create a facade that everything is okay when it's not. I don't have advice this time, but please know you're not alone.

I see a lot of posts about feeling alone, feeling like you don't have friends, and being unsure of how to make friends on campus.
When I first came to Brown I didn't feel like I really had a friend group until later in spring semester - before then, I felt like I couldn't connect to anyone. It seemed like everyone else had a solid friend group who they had so much fun with, and I started to think maybe it was because I wasn't interesting or because there were too many differences between me and other kids here. I considered transferring, too.
But it got better! I made one close friend, who introduced me to their friends, and through them I kept meeting new people. It's a lot easier to make new friends if you have someone to introduce you - and it's way more likely that you'll like the new people you'll meet too. 
It's easier said than done to go, ""just meet that one friend, through them you'll meet lots of other people"", but that's how it worked for me! If you meet someone who you think has a similar sense of humor to you, has similar interests, just reach out! Don't worry about looking desperate. You just gotta keep faking that confidence until you make it.

I really *admire* when students help each other out with meal swipes! Brown Meal Share is a sharing page where students can share their meal swipes to other students who really want a meal and are low on credits or off meal plan. Now is a great time to start offering your extra un-finishable swipes to folks who might be struggling to get meals during a difficult time! 

Sound too inconvenient maybe? Too much work? No worries, just offer your location (ex. Sci-li for the afternoon) and it's totally okay for you to have students meet you where you are for your card and then come back to return it! Thank you so much for your help. 

https://www.facebook.com/groups/BrownMealShare/?multi_permalinks=2186141674806187&comment_id=2186161768137511&notif_id=1544125511595376&notif_t=feedback_reaction_generic&ref=notif

An ode to dumpling:

The humble dumpling has two essential components: the filling and the encasing. Without either of these, the dumpling is no longer a dumpling but rather, much like myself, a massive disappointment. Those of us who have been consoled by the hopes that it is not what's on the outside that matters will be sadly disappointed to hear that the outside is the most important dumpling determiner. However fear not! Dumplings have shown mankind that it is possible to be soft, doughy, AND beautiful. In that vein, the outside of the dumpling must be starchy and dough-based and be formed of one (or at most two joined) pieces that can be wrapped or folded around the filling (dipping the filling into a batter and frying is not a dumpling that's just fried food which is also great but again, not. a. dumpling.). The filling, which we shall address in a moment, shall be almost completely encased by the wrapping. In this field, I am somewhat of a pioneer for my allowance of a small gap or hole. However, holes can be valuable as without one on your face you could never consume the delicious delicacy that is the dumpling. Nonetheless, we must be careful to limit this gap to a certain size. For example, a pita pocket is no longer a dumpling due to the large opening required to add the stuffing. The final criteria for the encasing is that it should be, in a sense, solid and able to hold its form under some duress. As a counterexample, let us examine a burrito. Although upon initial inspection we have a dumpling-like object, the fact of the matter is that a wrapped outside that has not been set by some form of cooking, such as steaming or boiling, can be easily unwrapped. In the instance where the casing and the filling can be separated with such ease, we have an entity that is, sadly, not a dumpling. 
At last we come to the filling of the dumpling. Some consider this a rather avant-garde approach, but I posit that the only thing that really matters is that a filling exists and is edible. These minimal criteria may, of course, lead to some very poor dumplings, but these are dumplings nonetheless. A dumpling exterior without a filling is only an empty shell of a dumpling and a social pariah of the dumpling world. But it is the happy union of an excellent filling and a dough-based exterior that forms a superior dumpling. And so we have the mighty dumpling.

I'm really going to miss the students I got the chance to TA this semester. Watching you all struggle with tough material and come out the other side has been so rewarding and inspiring. I know there were moments of frustration where you just wanted to yell/cry/give up because something wasn't working, but that's part of the reason I loved TA-ing this course - because in those moments I got the chance to watch you help each other, keep pushing, and ultimately figure out that you're all 100% capable. I hope you feel like you've learned something in the class, and I know many of you would make great TAs for next year's future students. I promise it will be one of the best things you do during your time at Brown.

Yours truly... TA

To the 5ish white guys really working through the ethics of using accents in comedy (?) in perfect English thank you for trying to be ethically responsible about it. You’ll probably never know what it feels like to be afraid of the shame that crawls in your throat for your father or your brother or yourself when they open their mouths to order food or greet someone or *speak* in “imperfect” English but I could see you were trying your best. Thanks.

Being queer at Brown has been such a painful experience. Growing up, all I ever saw was that it got better. I dreamed of getting into a place like Brown and now that I'm here, I still don't feel like I have the opportunity to be the guy that I dreamed of. There's not really a sense of community and even more so as a POC, I feel like I don't belong here.

I admire whoever can give me solid advice about my love life. 

I’m in a weird situation where I hooked up with a friend and aside from a few casual jokes, we haven’t really addressed it or acted differently toward each other. How do I broach the subject, whether that means romantic feelings or just hooking up more, without making things weird? I can’t tell if we’re both hiding behind humor and too scared to bring it up or if he genuinely just thinks it’s chill and doesn’t affect our friendship. I don’t mind if he doesn’t want to continue things, but it feels weird not to have closure at least. At the same time, i don’t want to come across as clingy and make our friendship weird when really I’m just curious what he’s thinking. Is this a Pandora’s Box that’s better left unopened?

i witnessed an incident several years ago, but every so often, i am reminded of it. today was one of those days.

i was making my way to andrews one afternoon, and i noticed a couple standing near the pembroke seal. they were arguing--not sure about what---but they both appeared rather flustered. as i approached, i witnessed the unthinkable: the girl began stomping on the pembroke seal furiously, repeatedly, shouting something along the lines of, ""you're stuck with me now!"", while her dude looked on, incredulous and--frankly--looking a bit petrified. it was one of the most savage things i have witnessed on this campus.

as i look back on this memory, i can't help but hope that their child has inherited its mother's nerve and vivacious attitude. i wish them all well.

A poem for the friend I had a crush on a while back:

The way your eyes light up when you’re excited
Your positive vibrations illuminating the space and people around you
I’m lucky to have met you
Lucky to have befriended you
Lucky to have loved you
Unlucky for you not to feel the same
Lucky to have deep feelings in the first place though
Better than the emptiness I usually feel.

Hope you find your place in life
Your passion, your drive
Recognize your ambitions 
Take risks and live life to the fullest
You deserve it.

i just want to say, to all the first years/sophomores/juniors that feel hopeless about making friends at this point: PLEASE don’t give up!! i can’t tell you how many breakdowns i had during my first three years here because i just DIDNT. KNOW. HOW. TO. MAKE. FRIENDS. i legitimately thought i was unlovable. i basically lost all hope by the beginning of this semester. and then something magical happened: i found my people!! i still don’t have a ton of friends, BUT, i do have a couple of really good ones that i can be myself around, and that i can call up to pass the time with and laugh a whole bunch; and really, that’s all that matters. :) so, please, do not give up hope yet! you are seen, you are loved, you are appreciated. and your people are out there. ❤️ love, a socially anxious senior who finally found her groove. 

p.s. if you feel like you need to reach out to someone about this but don’t know how, leave a comment or something and i’ll DM you and we can talk it out. :)

Cw: eating disorders

Here’s some appreciation for people in recovery/battling an eating disorder. It’s so draining and difficult to cope with an eating disorder much less be a student while doing it; it’s like a full time job on top of school, and it can be so discouraging and pervasive to try to manage everything/pursue recovery while doing school. On top of it all, eating disorders and eating disorder culture are really not discussed AT ALL at Brown and it can be so isolating and difficult to find resources and support systems that are consistent or helpful. 

So to all those struggling with eating disorders, you are seen, you are valuable, you are enough, you are not alone, and no matter where you are with ED right now, you’re experience is valid and you are managing an incredibly difficult thing and I’m proud of you for it. Just know that there is someone out there who is rooting for you and who believes in you and who thinks that you are amazing and resilient

2019 PSA/Resolution!:

In 2019, we’re shooting our shots with everyone we really want to be friends with or are crushing on. Do you have someone that you’ve been idly thinking for months that you’d like to get to know better? Do you have a major super-crush on a super kool kat? Have you been posting BBA posts telling someone to make a move or asking if someone would be down for a date but then never following up? Well that’s bad! Don’t do that!

Increasingly as I’ve reflected on why I haven’t asked out people I’m into -- either as potential friends or ~love interests~ -- I’ve come up blank. The truth is, if you ask someone out for coffee, __as long as you’re not creepy or weird about it, it’s not really that scary of an experience__. Here are some tippers!

A: Personally, when you’re first getting to know someone you might be _into_, I think it’s a _lot_ better to just ask them out for coffee and have it be a bit ambiguous if it’s a date-date or just a friend-date. If you explicitly label it as a date-date when you ask someone out, there’s a strong chance it will come off weirdly if you don’t know them very well, and there’s now a lot more pressure and expectations in the mix. People don’t want to go on a second “date” unless the first one goes really well, and if it doesn’t go really well, people tend to feel more awkward about it.

On the flip side, it’s a lot less weird to ask someone you don’t know that well out to coffee than it is to ask them to go on a _date_ with you. And in this case, you can still end up both having a great time and ending up ~into~ one another, but even if you don’t, you’re probably a bit closer now and would be willing to do it again some time as long as it doesn’t go super badly. And in the end, regardless of how they view it in their own head, good healthy relationships require you to get to know someone and be their friend, and good relationships can often take a long time to form or get started.

Feel free to disregard if you’re reasonably confident that both of you are ~into~ one another.

B: People like meeting new people! We all want friends! Most of us want to find love or companionship! As long as you’re not weird or creepy about it, if you ask someone out for coffee, they’ll probably be pretty excited or flattered that you think they’re ~kool~ enough that you felt the desire to reach out to them! Unless you give someone a reason to not like you or feel comfortable grabbing coffee with you, you really probably don’t have much to worry about.

C: Even if someone does say no, rejection isn’t really that scary. Honestly, what’s the big deal? Unless you make a big deal out of it and act weirdly around them for the rest of your life, no one really cares. Some of my current friends are people I had crushes on and told them, only for them to tell me they didn’t reciprocate. Some of my friends are people that told me they had crushes on me, only for me to tell them I didn’t feel the same way. It’s part of life. It’s not really weird unless you decide to make it weird!

With that all said, even if you know you should shoot your shot, it can be a bit hard to know what that looks like. Should you walk up to someone and ask them point blank? What exactly should you say? My personal opinion is that in most situations, hitting someone up on Messenger is usually the way to go, and you can just say something like

To someone you barely know (provide some motivation to how you know who they are):
“Hey, I know this is kinda like out of the blue, but I’ve [seen you around] (replace this with how you know of them if you know them through taking a class or something) and you seem really cool. Would you maybe be down to grab coffee sometime?”

To someone you know a little bit better:
“Hey, I know this is kind of out of the blue, but you seem really cool and I was wondering if you maybe would be down to grab coffee sometime?”

To someone you kind of consider a friend:
“Hey, do you want to maybe grab coffee sometime?”

If all of those are too awkward for you and you need to provide a little extra motivation, feel free to hit em with a
“Hey, I made a New Year’s resolution to try to reach out to people I’d like to get to know a little better. Would you maybe be down to grab coffee sometime?”
or a more general
“Hey, I’ve been trying hard lately to reach out to people that I’d like to get to know a bit better. Would you maybe be down to grab coffee sometime?”

If you have any critiques of these, or have better less awk feeling/more natural ways to say any of this, post in the comments below, although these ones have worked okay for me!

In the end though, I know a lot of people who are p lonely, and pretty much everyone I know wants to know a few extra people or to get ~close~ with someone, so I’mma make 2019 the year I shoot my shots, and I’m encouraging everyone else to too! (And I know this is an anonymous post, but please shoot your shots at me too!) Thnks, bye!

-me

CCB Appreciation Post:

Running for CCB last year was the best decision I ever made. I was a first-year and still trying to figure out what I wanted to get involved in at Brown. As a very anxious person, I didn't think I had what it took to run and win, but deciding to run changed my life. CCB is such a positive force in my life. Not only does my own class' board love and support me, the entirety of CCB has made me feel so welcome and validated. I've had incredible mentors and without them, I probably would not love being at Brown as much as I do. While I tell you all this at GB all of the time, I truly truly love you all so mcuh. CCB is like a family to me! Thank you for always empowering and supporting me. Again, I love you all so much ♥

i.

Stolen goddess from Greece's sand,
With Saturday's sweet shots consumed,
Borne back to Providence's land.
O, the victims she has wooed.
Atop the crude Emery floors,
Doth rest the angel that I've dreamed;
Alight my soul like Norway's fjords,
And ne'er her gold complexion dimm'd.
Of figures, stats her head obsessed,
With silky curves my eyes have met,
Untamed by British interest,
A caryatid in stone was set.
Her Grecian smile my loins doth stir,
With certainty, I would fuck her.
you have my number. use it.

Routines are both really important to me, and super hard for me. I've been reading a lot about the strength of practicing in routines helping people reach their goals, so I have been trying super hard lately to hold myself accountable and work on the things that are meaningful to me. This, of course, has had some stumblings, but I try. And it's tough because it's my own, solo effort. 

Anyway, backstory aside, the past few days as I've been walking down Thayer at 9 a.m. I've heard this beautiful violin music coming out of somewhere in Hegeman. I just wanted to shout out to you, violin player, diligently practicing in your own routine-- thanks for reminding me that, even if other people are working towards different goals than I am, we're all kind of in these routines together, striving to be better people who are better at the things we love to do. I know your practicing has nothing to do with me or my own writing practice, but I feel a sense of kinship with you, and wanted to say thanks.

To anybody who feels empty especially with all the Valentine’s hype:
You are not alone! It takes a LOT for two people to come together romantically, and many lovestories are fulfilled only after huge leaps of courage and sooo many compromises. And it’s even harder to maintain that relationship; so many don’t last for long, and while relationships serve as opportunities for people to emotionally mature, they are not the only way to do so. This may feel like empty words, but remember that you are beautiful and being by yourself is better than being with someone who’s toxic or only likes you for superficial reasons! Writing this for myself tbh because although I usually believe this the campus buzz got me feeling some sort of way

You know what I admire? My home cuisine. One of the really saddest moments I've felt as an international & POC student is when you're pushing your struggling ass through midterms season and just *miss home food so much,* but then realize your roomie or people in the lounge or people who walk into the kitchen will say it's ""nasty,"" ""smells like something's rotting,"" ""looks like shit,"" etc. everything I've heard as a little kid when I opened my lunchbox in a white setting.

Imagine living in a country halfway across the Earth from home, and you're doggedly studying for three exams so you just wanna microwave some comfort food, mac & cheese. Then as you take out excitedly you realize everyone around you thinks it looks like diarrhea and smells pungent, so you hide and gobble it hurriedly while your roommate's not home in the corner of your solitude. 

If we wanted to, we could say the same about common white food. Honestly, Chobani SMELLS. But I won't say anything when you open one in the library. I just miss home. And I wish I was less ashamed of the steamy, amazing food that brings me back to it but I am.

@6145 as a straight girl, I like being approached by guys. I think you have to do it in a way that isn't incredibly sexualized and that gives her space to leave. Like if you approach her and she seems uncomfortable you can ask respectfully if she wants you to leave (making it clear that you are totally okay with that) or just give her an out/leave yourself. Don't instigate a conversation based around her body, but compliments, including about her style choices are okay (hair color, dress, etc) so long as they aren't sexualized. If you can find a commonality or obvious talking point, that's best though. Not holding her up is ideal because you dont want her to feel trapped, so if things seem to be going well you can offer to give her your number. Don't ask for hers, because that can be super uncomfortable as a woman, but giving her yours gives her the autonomy and choice. Overall, treat her like a person, do not be overbearing and try to be cognizant of your privilege and her body language and you'll be okay

Dear friend that I’ve hooked up with (multiple times), I care ab you more than a pair of lips that are so nice to press against mine and bite, you are more than hair that pulls so easily, and wraps around my fingers. More than a body to become sweaty on top of mine. you have a laugh that would brighten any room and makes my eyes tighten and cheeks lift when I hear it. Your touch makes me pull apart the walls I’ve so carefully built to survive this disastrous campus, your hugs make me want to melt into your embrace. Your carefully, well out thoughts and attentive listening encourages me to talk on and on, and ensures me I’m never boring you. Your chuckle makes me blush - and laugh countlessly. When you lay next to me, I can’t help but put my head on top of your chest, because feeling your heart beat slow, and steady, makes mine drop to match it. Feeling the rise and fall of your chest makes me want to close my eyes and press my body closer to yours. Dear friend I’ve hooked up with, are we even friends?

With midterms coming up, I just want yall to know you got this. I've been here for a while and I've spent most of my time here comparing myself to others. I finally realized why I shouldnt. 

The first few years, I felt dumb in most of my classes. The times I had sections or had group study sessions, everyone else seemed to be so much more ahead of me. I convinced myself it was because they were either geniuses or they had perfect study schedules that my procrastinating ass couldn't keep up with. But the truth is, the geniuses probably just have background knowledge from other classes that make it easier for them to grasp. And the students with perfect study schedules just learn differently than me. 

All I'm saying is, I started to learn better again when I focused on me. When I focused on how I study best and that's it. Never feel you're dumb here or anywhere. If you screw up one test, you can do better on the other. It can get better, I swear.

I'm just sitting here thinking about the amazing friends I have because they unexpectedly and suddenly went out of their way to befriend me, even though we had never been close before. you know, not like the people you naturally gravitate towards over time or that you share common interests with, but the ones that put in the effort repeatedly because they really care. it makes me wonder how many more friends I would have if I had the courage to just. befriend someone that I have a friend crush on like that. I guess this is my way of saying that y'all should shoot your shots with anyone and everyone, even (especially) platonically! I'm so grateful these people are in my life and they probably wouldn't be if they weren't brave enough to make the first move. now go go go

Are you interested in love, sex, or sexuality? Want to contribute to a new publication at Brown?

XO is a new online magazine dedicated to the unsaid, the strange, the taboo, the foreign, the soft, the sharp, the blunt, the honest. We are committed to amplifying voices of the under-heard and stimulating discussion about the overlooked and the under-said. 

We aim to publish works of writing, media, and art that are focused on love, sex, and/or sexuality from current Brown and RISD students. We are particularly interested in reading creative non-fiction, but please send fiction, poems, and hybrid/digital works too. 

We are beginning an open, rolling call for submissions at the link below. Please visit https://www.xomagazine.org/ for information about how to submit, as well as to sign up for our listserv.

I miss hearing you call me by the various nicknames you gave me. I miss talking about our life together. I miss coming home to you. I miss going to our secret hideaways together. I miss celebrating each and every month we shared. I miss telling you I love you. I miss being yours. I miss writing you notes. I miss holding your hand. I miss taking random naps and not waking up for hours. I miss our late night conversations. I miss the sound of your voice. I miss every ritual we established. I miss the feeling of assurance you always gave me. I miss being able to share good news with you. I miss watching you put your glasses on in the very particular way. I miss making memories with you. I miss what we had. I will always want to be yours.
